Confusion about factorization algebras

Apr 25, 2020

In this brief post, I’d like to talk about something I’m confused about. The question is: what is the precise relationship between factorization algebras and -algebras? Here’s how I would like it to go. Let be a smooth complex variety. The Riemann-Hilbert correspondence gives an equivalence between regular holonomic D-modules on and constructible sheaves on , given by the de Rham/solutions functor. Let’s suppose we can somehow apply this to , where is a smooth algebraic curve (this can’t be done literally, because is just a functor. Whatever.). Then, we obtain a comparison between regular holonomic D-modules on and constructible sheaves on .

Here is where I get confused.

  • Let , so . We know that -algebras in topology correspond to sheaves on which are constructible with respect to a particular stratification (namely, the order stratification on ), whereas the Riemann-Hilbert correspondence just constructs a sheaf on which is constructible for some stratification. Maybe this is obviously not an issue (perhaps because is contractible)?
  • Is it obvious that the factorizability condition on D-modules on realizes under the de Rham/solutions functor to the factorizability condition on ? It seems like this is in fact not the case! But I’m probably missing something…

However, here’s one thing you can do to get an -space from an ind-proper factorization space (following this paper). Let’s say that , and let be a factorization space over . To describe a (nonunital) -space , I just have to tell you a space for every disk , and coherent maps for every inclusion of disks, such that for every embedding of disks, the induced map is an equivalence (“local constancy”). So, suppose ; then, you get an inclusion , and is defined to be the preimage of under .

The factorization condition on now gets you coherent maps for every inclusion of disks. How about local constancy? This is the hard part, but I think by arguing as in Jeremy’s and Allen’s paper, it’s true that if is such that is ind-proper for every finite set , then the canonical map is an equivalence for every . This obviously implies local constancy.

Although nice, this isn’t terribly terribly satisfying… It’s not like the Riemann-Hilbert correspondence, which tells you that upon putting some restrictions on allowed singularities, you get an identification between topological information (constructible sheaves) and algebraic information (D-modules). So: what is the analogue of Riemann-Hilbert for factorization spaces and -spaces?
